summary: Internal FBI New York Field Office emails from March 2020 discussing COVID-19 operational adjustments, including telework policies and the status of evidence handling for several high-profile cases, including those of Jeffrey Epstein and Peter Nygard. The emails reveal FBI agents were actively managing evidence from these cases during the pandemic.

persons.name: SSA - FBI New York
persons.context: Author of the squad-specific email providing guidance on office access, telework, and case evidence management during COVID-19. Leads the Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad.

persons.name: Assistant Director in Charge
persons.role: Assistant Director in Charge, FBI New York Field Office
persons.context: Author of the broader NYO (New York Office) update email establishing COVID-19 protocols, designating all employees as mission critical, and setting telework and office occupancy guidelines.

connections.description: The SSA is implementing the broader office policies (regarding telework and office access) set by the Assistant Director in Charge for their specific squad.

events.title: FBI NYO COVID-19 Policy Implementation
events.description: The Assistant Director in Charge of the FBI New York Field Office issues a directive designating all employees as mission critical but requiring telework where possible, limiting office occupancy to 20% per squad to mitigate COVID-19 spread.

events.title: Squad C-20 Evidence Management Discussion
events.description: The SSA of Squad C-20 emails the squad detailing office logistics, noting that specific agents possess boxes of evidence from the Epstein, Nygard, and Ray cases, and that agents can work on case-related tasks from home.

keyFacts: The FBI's New York Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad (C-20) was actively managing evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein, Peter Nygard, and an individual named 'Ray' as of March 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic forced the FBI NY office to implement strict telework policies, limiting physical office presence to 20% of any squad while maintaining all employees on 'mission critical' status.
The document indicates that arrests, grand juries, and indictments were potentially slowed due to court orders during the early pandemic period.
The email chain reveals the operational continuity challenges faced by law enforcement investigating major cases during a national crisis.
Specific agents are noted as having custody of evidence boxes for the named cases, indicating ongoing investigative activity.
